description: From un- +‎ light or, in the case of the verb, perhaps from Middle English *unlighten (suggested by past participle unlight, unlyght, unliȝt (“unlit”)), equivalent to un- +‎ light.

entries.meaning: (literary or poetic) The absence of light; darkness.
examples: “They move and shake, from the unlight! The unlight which blackensss and ssscarsss!” “These men, are they a threat to us? To our plans for these lands?” “They are a threat to the way of thingsss! They count among them powerful magii and  […] ”

verbs.description: unlight (third-person singular simple present unlights, present participle unlighting, simple past and past participle unlighted or unlit)

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare) To extinguish, turn off, or dim the light from
examples: His father, in another room, unlights the lamp and leaves the world alone.

description: From Middle English unlighten (“to lighten the burden of; alleviate; dismount from horseback”), equivalent to un- +‎ light (“to alight”).

verbs.description: unlight (third-person singular simple present unlights, present participle unlighting, simple past and past participle unlighted)

examples: I would rather take the water unmixed," said I. "Just as you like," said the old soldier; "but please to unlight, and come into my barracks, at all events."

description: From Middle English unlight, unlyght, unliȝt (“not light (in weight)”), equivalent to un- +‎ light.

examples: And thought to bere him doun; With a launce unlight, He smote him in the lyoun; And Tristrem that was wight  […]
